docs.abstract: If you believe you were discharged from the military because you are an immigrant, we want to hear from you.
docs.snippet: If you believe you were discharged from the military because you are an immigrant, we want to hear from you.
docs.lead_paragraph: For years, the Defense Department has offered immigrants in the United States a fast track to citizenship through military service, but on Thursday, the Associated Press reported that it knew of as least 40 men and women who had been recruited into the Army and then unexpectedly discharged before meeting the required time in service to be naturalized. The report follows recent policy changes under the Trump administration that have led the armed forces to beef up security checks of foreign-born recruits before they reach basic training. If you have been unexpectedly discharged from the military because of your immigration status, we want to hear from you for a coming story.

headline.main: Have You Been Discharged From the Army Because You Are an Immigrant?

docs.abstract: Sixty-two security force members, one American soldier and 37 civilians were killed during the past week.
docs.snippet: Sixty-two security force members, one American soldier and 37 civilians were killed during the past week.
docs.lead_paragraph: Beginning in September, the Times bureau in Kabul mobilized all of its stringers and Afghan reporters to record every attack on the Afghan security forces that they could find, as a daily chronicle of the war. In this week’s edition, we are adding reports of civilian casualties.

docs.abstract: This ghazal, a traditional Middle Eastern/Persian/Indian poem, creates a spell that builds in power and circles around mystery.
docs.snippet: This ghazal, a traditional Middle Eastern/Persian/Indian poem, creates a spell that builds in power and circles around mystery.
docs.lead_paragraph: Bahr is Arabic for “sea” but means “meter” when applied to poetry. Zeina Hashem Beck weaves poems of deep longing that feel like whole worlds. This ghazal, a traditional Middle Eastern/Persian/Indian poem, creates a spell that builds in power and circles around mystery — “back home” being so hard to get to, for countless people on earth yearning for ways of passage, safety, arrival. Habibi means “darling.” Selected by Naomi Shihab Nye

byline.original: By Zeina Hashem Beck and Naomi Shihab Nye

docs.abstract: The lives of two painters, Celia Paul and Cecily Brown, tell very different stories about what it takes to thrive in a medium historically dominated by men.
docs.snippet: The lives of two painters, Celia Paul and Cecily Brown, tell very different stories about what it takes to thrive in a medium historically dominated by men.
docs.lead_paragraph: In a recent feature film about the sculptor Alberto Giacometti, we find the great man in his Paris studio, brooding over the difficulty of giving birth to his own genius. Fuming and raging, lashing out at his familiars, he is a chain-smoking wild beast being kept in cultural captivity. His growing fame brings admirers to his freezing workshop, where they wonder at his ascetic indifference to discomfort, and still more — gifted as he surely is — at his capacity for self-criticism. Not that his manhood can be in any doubt: He flaunts his ravishing young mistress before his careworn, miserable wife, who nonetheless remains his devoted slave in the fervent belief that she is the one who truly understands him. In one scene, in a fit of furious dissatisfaction, he hurls a sheaf of sketches into a flaming brazier before a group of astonished onlookers. The camera shows the horror on their faces as they watch the artworks burn, a horror it is assumed we share. It isn’t just the sight of Giacometti’s sketches going up in smoke that appalls us; it’s the fact that, to our retrospective eyes, he might as well be burning thousand-dollar bills.

headline.main: Can a Woman Who Is an Artist Ever Just Be an Artist?

docs.abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on intervening when an employee works too much and holding onto an inheritance.
docs.snippet: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on intervening when an employee works too much and holding onto an inheritance.
docs.lead_paragraph: I am on the board of a small nonprofit. We have a part-time director who drives herself relentlessly on behalf of our organization, working perhaps two to three times the hours required of her. I live nearby, and occasionally I have observed her car parked outside the office all night long.

headline.main: What Should I Do About the Workaholic Who Works for Me?
headline.print_headline: What Should I Do About the Workaholic Who Works for Me?
